titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lessons of the Sixties: A history of local Washington, DC activism for peace and justice from 1960-1975:Personal papers, 1937-2016, bulk 1967-1981 MS2392
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Lessons of the Sixties: A history of local Washington, DC activism for peace and justice from 1960-1975: Personal papers
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.
did.abstract:
Lessons of the Sixties is an organization dedicated to documenting the efforts and lessons learned by local DC Metropolitan Area activists, students, organizers and those who dreamed of building a better world through new ideas, political advocacy, local organization building, and other means in the years 1960-1975. Since 2010, the Institute for Policy Studies has served as the organizational home for the Lessons of the 60s providing office space and infrastructural support. Since 2010 the project volunteers have interviewed more than 80 local activists, students, organizers and those who dreamed of building a better world through new ideas, political advocacy, local organization building, and various other means in the Washington, D.C. area in the years 1960-1975. At times during the interviews the interviewees would use personal records as examples or memory prompts. Those records were also donated to GW Special Collections and comprise a more encompassing collection of records of this time period in Washington D.C.'s history.
Lessons of the Sixties is an organization dedicated to documenting the efforts and lessons learned by local DC Metropolitan Area activists, students, organizers and those who dreamed of building a better world through new ideas, political advocacy, local organization building, and other means in the years 1960-1975. This collection contains paper records donated by participants in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. These paper records including newspaper articles, correspondence, newsletters, pamphlets, images, and buttons. These documents cover many topics including school reform, reprodutive rights, labor issues, anti-vietnam war and government worker rights. These records cover 1937-2016 with the bulk of the records covering 1967-1981.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be governed by copyright. For activities that the researcher determines fall under fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. Researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights, determining if the intended re-use falls under fair use, and obtaining approval from the copyright holder if the intended use does not fall under fair use. Please contact Special Collections if the copyright status of the materials you wish to reuse is unclear. Staff will provide additional information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 14 series: Dale Brown papers, Irene Elkin papers, Jan Fenty buttons, Madeleine Golde papers, John Hanrahan papers, Norman Oslik papers, Natasha Reatig papers, Irv Riskin papers, Fred Solowey papers, Roberta Spalter-Roth papers, Marcia Sprinkle-Kopit papers, Alice Wolfson papers, Malcolm Davis papers and Larry Aaronson draft of memoir.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Lessons of the Sixties, 2019 November 21 (2019.101)
All these paper records were given to the donor by participants of the oral history project and become the property of the donor to deposit at GW.

bioghist.head: Historical
bioghist.p: Lessons of the Sixties is an organization dedicated to documenting the efforts and lessons learned by local DC Metropolitan Area activists, students, organizers and those who dreamed of building a better world through new ideas, political advocacy, local organization building, and other means in the years 1960-1975. The organization's goal is to make materials easily available for future activists, historians, students, writers, and media producers. Members have given presentations on their findings in order to facilitate direct dialogue between generations of social justice activists. One of the most significant contributions are the oral histories it conducted between 2010-2019 with local activists. Lessons of the 60s has the objective of focusing on key local and national movements and events of this period in which D.C-area-based residents were involved. These topics include, but are not limited to, 1963 March on Washington, anti-Vietnam War organizing, Black power movement, civil rights movement, DC statehood movement, early battles against gentrification, fair housing, international solidarity, May Day 1971, peace movement, Stop the North Central Freeway/3 Sisters Bridge, student activism for peace and civil rights, and the Women's movement.
Since 2010 the Institute for Policy Studies has served as the organizational home for the Lessons of the 60s providing office space and infrastructural support

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains paper records donated by participants in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. These paper records including newspaper articles, correspondence, newsletters, pamphlets, images, and buttons. These documents cover many topics including school reform, reprodutive rights, labor issues, anti-vietnam war and government worker rights. Each series is the donation of a separate interviewee. The donors provided keywords for specific folders that have been included as notes for those specific folders. These records cover 1937-2016 with the bulk of the records covering 1967-1981.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The donor provided keywords for many of the folders. These were added to general notes for those folders. For series 12 the keywords were for all the folders in one paragraph. Thus, for that series the general note with the keywords is at the series level.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: High school activist who was arrested distributing anti-Vietnam War material at a military base. Also headed up a students' committee against the war in 1971 for May Day, an attempted shut-down of the US government by the peace movement.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes documents from Dale Brown's high school student activism against the Vietnam War, focused around 1971.

relatedmaterial.head: oral history
relatedmaterial.p: Dale Brown was a participant in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. The interview is part of collection MS2388. Listen to the interview. .

odd.head: General

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Irene Elkin has been an activist from the 1950s through the 2010s. During the 1960s and early 1970s, she was chair of the Schools Committee of the Adams-Morgan Community Council, fighting successfully for community control of Morgan School (now the Marie Reed Community Learning Center). As a government employee, Elkin was active in the Vietnam Moratorium Committee at NIH/NIMH (VNMC) and Federal Employees for Peace. On the Moratorium Committee, she served as one of the coordinators of the group and was one of the plaintiffs in a case brought against the Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare for use of the NIH auditorium for speakers invited by the VNMC.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from Irene Elkin's participation in the successful efforts during the 1960s and early 1970s to establish community control of Morgan School in the Adams-Morgan neighborhood of Washington, D.C.

relatedmaterial.head: oral history
relatedmaterial.p: Jan Fenty was a participant in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. The interview is part of collection MS2388. Listen to the interview. .

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Madeleine Golde came to Washington, DC in 1967 in the era of President Johnson's Great Society programs to try to make a difference in terms of social programs for the poor. During her seven years in HEW, she was an outspoken activist against the war in Vietnam within the federal bureaucracy, including helping to form government-wide anti-war organizations; launched an underground newspaper, The Advocate, that circulated widely throughout the Dept for 5 years, tackling issues ranging from treatment of minorities in HEW, to effectiveness of HEW programs and free speech rights for employees; and played an important role in activating a moribund union local in her Department. For the past 40 years, she has continued to be an active participant in advocating for the rights of workers and the protection of our communities.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents covering Madeleine Golde's activist work during the years 1968-1975, including her leadership of the The Advocate newsletter, her union-related work including HEW Local 41 and the Coalition for Labor Union Women, and her work government-wide organizing through her involvement in Federal Employees Against the War in Vietnam, Federal Employees for a Democratic Society and Federal Employees for Peace. The Advocate was an independent newsletter published by and for Department of Health, Education and Welfare employees in the Washington, D.C. area. It was designed to be a vehicle to examine and critique the programs and policies of the Department as well as larger political issues such as the War in Vietnam. It also included information on activities of interest to HEW employees. It was initially designed as a monthly newsletter. It began in February, 1968 and the last issue appeared in the Spring of 1973. In total, 47 issues were published. It was widely distributed and read throughout HEW in the Washington area and faced multiple legal challenges from the leadership of HEW.

relatedmaterial.head: oral history
relatedmaterial.p: Madeleine Gold was a participant in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. The interview is part of collection MS2388. Listen to the interview. .

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The donation from Madeleine Golde included digital copies of the Advocate. These are housed on the Special Collections preservation server. These items can not be uploaded yet because they are not yet in compliance with the University's accessibility guidelines. The paper copies are available, but if you would like a pdf copy please request one from staff.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Delivered by Lessons of the Sixties in February 2021. Part of accession 2019.101.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Information provided by the donor: Federal Employees for A Democratic Society (FEDS) was formed in the Spring of 1968. FEDS grew out of an effort by a number of federal employees from different agencies to circulate a government-wide petition against the war in Vietnam. FEDS was intended to be a more permanent organization of federal employees representing a broad range of federal agencies in the Washington Metropolitan Area. It's mission was to not only address issues of the war but to examine federal programs with the focus of making them more responsive to the needs of the constituents they were intended to serve. The FEDS banner was used in a number of demonstrations and activities that were held over around a two-year period into 1970. During this period FEDS helped organize active agency-based groups, held regular meetings to organize government-wide anti-war activities, carried out a conference designed to look at a number of key social policy issues and employee rights issues, and ran a regular film festival related to important issues of the day.

did.unittitle: Federal Employees for Peace digital copies of photographs some from publications

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The digital images in this folder came to Special Collections in February 2021 from the Lesson of the Sixties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The digital files in this donation include the following:
1. Daniel Ellsberg at dinner in his honor, Undated
2. Ellsberg dinner - audience, Undated
3. Ellsburg dinner - declassified stamp, Undated
4. Federal Employees for Peace rally sign (jpg version), Circa 1972
5. Federal Employees for Peace rally sign (pdf version), Circa 1972

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: These images are only in digital form and are not online. Please seek assistance from staff for access to these images.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Information provided by the donor: Federal Employees for Peace (FEPS) - FEPS came into being at the end of 1970. FEPS served a coalition bringing together representatives of many federal agency Vietnam Moratorium Committees, American Federation of Government Employee locals, agency discussion groups, and individual federal employees commited to ending the war. It was primarily focused on continuing efforts to organize efforts throughout the government in the Washington DC area to end the war in Vietnam. The organization ceased to be once the war ended in 1975. The banner was used in many anti-war rallies throughout this period. Among its many activities, FEPS also held a very successful dinner in September of 1971 to honor Daniel Ellsberg for releasing the Pentagon Papers, and conducted a referendum on the Vietnam War among Federal employees, with 83% of 7,407 employees from across the government voting to end the war. The banner was again used by current and former federal employees in demonstrations opposing the Iraq War in 2003.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Hanrahan is a former Washington Post reporter/union activist in support of 1975 pressmen's strike at the Post; also a DC community activist on voting rights, other local issues.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the D.C. Statehood Movement. The subjects and people include many key local activists of the 1960s-1970s such as Julius Hobson, Hilda Mason, Charles Mason, Josephine (Jo) Butler, Sammie Abbott, Brint Dillingham,, Selma Rein; Anti-War Demonstrations; Anti-Freeway Fight; Civil rights, and extensive coverage of the Washington Post Pressmen's Strike years 1975-1977.

relatedmaterial.head: oral history
relatedmaterial.p: John Hanrahan was a participant in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. The interview is part of collection MS2388. Listen to the interview. .

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Norman Oslik's first activism began when he joined the Vietnam Moritorium Committee at NIH/NIMH in 1970 as part of his growing opposition to the war in Vietnam. During this period he also worked on various labor and community issues with the Alliance for Labor and Community Action, including helping to publish a community newsletter, supporting workers in various labor conflicts and working on the Alliance's Unemployment Committee. Over the next several decades he has continued his activism in a variety of arenas, including local environmental protection issues, community involvement in local development projects, and union organizing as well as serving for six years as an elected Town Council Member.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series covers Norman Oslik's work in the anti-Vietnam War movement with the NIH/NIMH Vietnam Moratorium Committee, and his worker support activities through the the Alliance for Labor and Community Action and the Alliance Unemployment Committee.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Natasha Reatig was an active participant and leader in the Vietnam Moratorium Committee at NIH/NIMH, the Federal Employees for Peace and the League of Federal Voters, during the late 1960s and early 1970s, working to educate federal employees and mobilize them to help end the war in Vietnam.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from Natasha Reatig's work with Federal employees to end the war in Vietnam during the late 1960s and early 1970s, including restrictions on free speech rights of employees by senior government officials.

odd.head: General

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Irv Riskin was a union organizer, a McCarthy-era political witch-hunt victim, and a life-long activist for peace and social justice. His Washington area activities included leadership in the Gray Panthers and the Grape Boycott, and as a key Washington Post strike supporter, and mentor to a generation of social justice activists in Washington, D.C.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from Irv Riskin's active involvement in the bitter Washington Post newspaper strike of 1975-1977.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Irv Riskin was a participant in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. The interview is part of collection MS2388. Listen to the interview.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: A native New Yorker, Fred Solowey has lived in Washington, DC since October, 1973. He worked full time coordinating the efforts of the Local Six Legal Defense Committee, during the Washington Post strike and its aftermath. Active in many organizations, he helped found and coordinated the Washington Area Labor Committee on Central America and the Caribbean and was the founding executive director of the Coalition to End Grand Jury Abuse. For the past 35 years he has been a labor journalist and editor for a number of unions.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series has materials covering many areas of Fred Solowey's activism in the early 1970s, including the campaign to impeach President Nixon, DC Statehood efforts, the DC Bank Campaign against redlining, DC labor activism, the community response to the murder of Yulanda Ward, the Citywide Housing Coalition, the McSurely V. McClellan court case challenging Congressional immunity for wrongdoing, and police brutality and the Terrence Johnson case in Prince George's County.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Marcia Sprinkle was influenced as a teenager by the civil rights movement, joined SNCC (Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee) while in college and moved to Washington, D.C. to continue her activism. She worked for many years as a community organizer, working primarily "across the color line" as a white person working in the black community.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series cover Marcia Sprinkle's involvement in the campaign in the late 1960s to establish a community-run school in the Adams Morgan neighborhood of Washington, D.C. Participants were parents, activists, teachers and other school personnel who were involved in that campaign. The papers also include her work with the Children's House day care program, which evolved from an unlicensed coop in the late 1960s to a fully licensed childcare center operating for 10 years. Participants were also active in pushing for the Brademas bill, the first legislation for national funding and standards for childcare subsequently vetoed by President Nixon as "socialist". They also spearheaded the work to create a childcare center at Georgetown Hospital and organized for childcare funding at the city level as well as providing childcare for a number of national organizations meeting in DC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Alice Wolfson is a veteran political activist and a pioneer in the women's health movement. She belonged to DC Women's Liberation, and was a member of "The Daughters of Lilith" collective. Hers was one of the leading voices protesting the lack of female participation in the 1970 Pill Hearings, as well as the deliberate withholding of information regarding oral contraceptives' dangerous side effects. Alice was one of the founders of the National Women's Health Network (NWHN) and organized many other actions during the NWHN's early years, including a sit-in in the office of the Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, and the first FDA Protest. Alice served on the NWHN board of directors for several years. She also co-founded the Committee to Defend Reproductive Rights, which fought for and won both California state regulations protecting women against sterilization abuse and court decisions guaranteeing MediCal coverage of abortion. Today, Alice is a lawyer fighting for the rights of disabled individuals who have been discriminated against by their insurance companies.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series are from Alice Wolfson's activism and policy work in the reproductive rights movement.

odd.head: General

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Malcolm Davis (1937-2011) - was an Ecumenical campus chaplain at George Washington University (GWU) from 1967 until 1984. Throughout the late 1960s-early 1970s, Davis's campus office served as a gathering and planning spot for civil rights and antiwar activists. Davis personally fought for social justice -- in the South organizing civil rights bus caravans and sit-ins, leading voter registration drives, confronting the Ku Klux Klan; in D.C. helping organize the Poor People's Campaign and its accompanying Resurrection City in 1968, and helping organize anti-war protests during the Vietnam War. He later became renowned for his porcelain pottery. Panel participants, all of whom were student activists at George Washington during the late 1960s and early 1970s, were: Sally Benbasset Tim Frasca Lexi Freeman Richard Lipsitz Esther Siegel George Virkus.
Biography provided by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents and newspaper clippings that cover the part of Malcolm Davis' campus ministry at GWU, in the People's Union.The materials date from the early to middle 1970s.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project, Malcolm Davis was remembered by Sally Benbasset, Tim Frasca, Lexi Freeman, Richard Lipsitz, Esther Siegel, and George Virkus. All of whom were student activists at George Washington during the late 1960s and early 1970s. The interview titled "Malcolm Davis Remembered" is part of collection MS2388. Listen to the interview.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Delivered by Lessons of the Sixties in February 2021. Part of accession 2019.101.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Larry Aaronson was a participant in the Lessons of the Sixties oral history project. The interview is part of collection MS2388. Listen to the interview. .

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Larry Aaronson grew up in Washington DC, where he began a teaching career after college. He cut his political teeth in the local civil rights movement, moving later to Cambridge, MA to teach in public schools for over forty years. Larry maintains that he has learned more from his hundreds of students than they ever learned from him.
Biography provided by the donor.
